articles.title: Daniel Cormier REACTS to Justin Gaethje BEATING Paddy Pimblett, Sean O'Malley defeats Song Yadong
articles.description: Daniel Cormier IS BACK from octagon side after an incredible main event fight between Justin Gaethje and Paddy Pimblett at UFC 324 to give his post-fight analysis! DC talks about how Gaethje was able to defeat Pimblett and impose his will on the fight from the start. Plus, Cormier gives his flowers to Pimblett, and says DOUBTERS HAVE TO STOP questioning Paddy after a tough, resilient performance for the interim belt. DC also talks Sean O'Malley's win over Song Yadong, and how special the moment was for Suga Sean in hopes to once again be UFC champion. And don't miss Daniel react to Waldo's KO vs. Derrick Lewis, Jean Silva getting a win over Arnold Allen, and so much more from the UFC's official first card with Paramount plus! All lines provided by @hardrockbet Follow me on all social media platforms! A headline coming out of weigh-ins claimed Patty Pimblett held a size advantage over Justin Gaethje. That claim doesn‚Äôt survive even a basic look at how weight classes actually work. Both fighters weighed in at 155 pounds. That‚Äôs not a suggestion, not a range ‚Äî it‚Äôs a hard number. At that point, size advantages don‚Äôt exist. Lightweight is lightweight. Enough is enough. In this video, Chael Sonnen breaks down why face-off photos and surface-level narratives keep misleading fans during fight week. He explains how gyms actually separate athletes by real size, why fighters within certain ranges are effectively the same weight, and why ‚Äúsize advantage‚Äù headlines often collapse under scrutiny. Ends 1/25/26 at 11:59 PM ET. Sponsored by DK. Why is this fight happening ‚Äî and what does it actually lead to? Cameron Smotherman made weight ‚Äî and then his body gave out. He stepped on the scale at 135.5 pounds, officially cleared the limit, took a few steps, and collapsed moments later. No theatrics. No exaggeration. Just a visible example of what extreme weight cutting can look like when the margin disappears. The moment wasn‚Äôt about the fall itself. It was about the fact that Smotherman still made weight. That detail matters. Whatever misery the cut required, whatever strain it placed on the body, the job was finished before the system failed. That is toughness ‚Äî and it also highlights a problem the sport continues to acknowledge without meaningfully fixing. This issue has been solved before. The NCAA ended extreme weight cutting decades ago, not through discussion panels or medical speculation, but by changing the weigh-in window. When athletes were required to compete shortly after weighing in, dehydration stopped immediately. The incentive disappeared. A weigh-in held a full day before competition is no longer functional. It serves marketing purposes, not competitive ones. Fighters rehydrate, reconstitute, and often enter the cage at drastically different weights than what was measured. Fighters are adults, and they will always pursue advantages within the rules. But there is a cost ‚Äî and this time, that cost was caught on video. The hope is that Smotherman is healthy and recovers fully. The larger hope is that moments like this finally lead to action instead of repetition. In this video, I explain what that conversation wasn‚Äôt about ‚Äî and more importantly, what it realistically could have been about. Jake Paul‚Äôs contract with the Professional Fighters League is over. Dana White is producing a historic UFC event tied to the White House setting. And Trump? He‚Äôs Trump ‚Äî he talks to everyone. None of that automatically equals a fight booking. The UFC doesn‚Äôt book novelty matches. It doesn‚Äôt throw together ‚Äúcool-sounding‚Äù fights with no rankings, no stakes, and no future. Every matchup has meaning, direction, and consequence. That‚Äôs why ideas like Jake Paul debuting on a White House card don‚Äôt survive even a basic reality check. The current main event featuring Paddy Pimblett and Justin Gaethje feels less like a true lightweight title fight and more like a co-main event filling space. That wasn‚Äôt supposed to be the plan. The original direction pointed toward Ilia Topuria versus Arman Tsarukyan ‚Äî a clean, undisputed story at 155. But circumstances changed. Injuries, timing, and negotiations reshuffled the deck, and now the card feels like a watered-down version of what the division actually deserves. Here‚Äôs where it gets interesting: while others stayed quiet, Tsarukyan has been out front doing the media rounds, carrying the promotional load, and publicly calling out the lack of effort around him. That‚Äôs not accidental. That‚Äôs a fighter positioning himself as Plan B ‚Äî the insurance policy when cards fall apart. Backup fighters matter. They train. They cut weight. They show up. And historically, almost every backup fighter ends up fighting for the belt ‚Äî with one notable exception. Asking the same fighter to do it again without guarantees is where things get complicated. The UFC just lost its co-main event and its only undisputed title fight. In moments like that, you don‚Äôt need perfect answers ‚Äî you need someone willing to say yes and protect the card. Right now, that someone appears to be Arman Tsarukyan.
